doc.name: revOpenDatabase
doc.summary: Connects to a MySQL, SQLite, PostgreSQL, ODBC or Oracle database.

examples.example: get revOpenDatabase("odbc", "BizFile", , "jenkins" ,the dbPassword of me, "emulated static")
get revOpenDatabase("mysql", "localhost", "dbName", myUsr, myPass, false, "/var/mysql.sock", 1, true)

description.overview: Use the revOpenDatabase function to start working with a database.

parameter.name: databaseType
parameter.description: A string specifying the database type to use. One of the following:

parameter.name: host
parameter.description: A string specifying the IP address or domain name of the system hosting the database. For SQLite databases, the host should be the full path to the database file.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.description: (SQLite Only) A string specifying the path to the SQLite database.

parameter.name: port
parameter.description: A number specifying the port number you want to connect to, and is used only for MySQL and PostgreSQL databases. If no port is specified, MySQL database connections use port 3306 and PostgreSQL database connections use port 5432.

parameter.name: databaseName
parameter.description: A string specifying the the name of the database to connect to. For SQLite databases, the database name should be left empty.

parameter.name: userName
parameter.description: A string specifying your authorized user name for the database (Some databases do not require a user name).

parameter.name: password
parameter.description: A string specifying the authentication password for the userName (Some databases do not require a password).

parameter.name: useSSL
parameter.description: (MySQL Only) A boolean specifying whether to use SSL to secure the socket connection when connecting to a MySQL database. If you use this feature in a standalone application, remember to select 'SSL & Encryption' from among the available 'script libraries' in the standalone application settings panel.

parameter.name: socket
parameter.description: (MySQL Only) A string specifying the socket or named pipe the driver should use to connect with. If empty, the default for the host will be used.

parameter.name: timeout
parameter.description: (MySQL Only) A number specifying the database read/write timeout in whole seconds. Defaults to 20 seconds if empty or not a positive integer. If 0, the connection never times out.

parameter.name: autoReconnect
parameter.description: (MySQL Only) A boolean specifying if the driver should attempt to automatically reconnect to the database when the connection is lost. A reconnection attempt will be made the next time a command is executed.

parameter.name: cursorType
parameter.description: (ODBC Only) A string specifying the type of cursor to use.

option.description: This is a scrollable static cursor. Using this cursor it is possible to navigate backwards as well as forwards through record sets, and to move straight to the first or last record. Static cursors operate on an "offline" copy of the data, meaning that any changes to the data will not be detected by the cursor. Not all ODBC drivers support static cursors, for example FileMaker 6 does not.

This is a cursor that can be scrolled forwards only. All ODBC drivers must support this type of cursor. Forward only cursors are usually faster than scrollable static cursors, but using revMoveToPreviousRecord, revMoveToFirstRecord or revMoveToLastRecord will fail. Forward only is the default cursor type, and is what was used in LiveCode 2.8.1 and earlier.

This cursor has the same behavior as a static cursor, except it allows ODBC to emulate the cursor's behavior if the driver does not support it. ODBC can typically emulate static cursor behavior on Windows systems only.

description.value:
The revOpenDatabase function returns a database ID which can be used to refer to the database in other Database library commands and functions. The database ID is always an integer.
If the database is not successfully opened, the revOpenDatabase function returns an error message. The error message is never an integer, so you can check whether the connection was successful by checking whether the return value is an integer or not.

comments.note: To use a DSN to identify an ODBC database, use the DSN as the host, and leave the databaseName parameter empty.
comments.important: The revOpenDatabase function is part of the Database library. To ensure that the function works in a standalone application, you must include this custom library when you create your standalone. In the Inclusions section of the General screen of the Standalone Application Settings window, make sure the "Database Support" checkbox is checked and the database drivers you are using are selected in the list of database drivers.
